Since the build is currently broken, may be worth waiting for Luke's fix to get in and then rebase/fix.
@jbonofre Let me know how I can help. This is becoming important for our work to de-google-ify the examples and IO code.
Minor nit that I'll clean up on merge is that the javadoc that references complex parameters has generally left the () off, for example in DoFn.java
In the commit message, you mean static constructors of `WindowingStrategy`?
LGTM - except a few minor comments

After this PR, is the default logging same in BlockingDataflowRunner, logs job messages to System.out?

And, how users change to log job messages to file, through slf4j config file? I think users also want to config workers logging and PipelineRunner.run() logging separately.

Changes Unknown when pulling **2efe7617a595b8ac6167db40724d9874afd6df23 on francesperry:master** into *\* on apache:master**.
No, with the methods on `Window.Bound` that modify that `PTransform`

I believe that the previous build failure is flakiness due to a TOCTU bug in `FileIOChannelFactory#create` - namely, we check to see if a directory exists and then if not call `mkdirs`, and fail if the `mkdirs` returns false; however, if the directory has been created between the two calls, `mkdirs` returns false but the file exists.

I've added a second check to ensure that we don't fail improperly.

R: @chamikaramj 

Please review. Thank you for noticing these problems. I reverted the changes in group_with_coder_test.

This changes the logging of job messages to use the SLF4J logger which will delegate logging to any logger the user has configured for the SLF4J backend. For example, if they configure their application to use log4j, then they can have a log4j config which sets the log level and output location in their log4j.properties file. They can use any supported SLF4J backend logger like log4j, JUL, JCL, ... and associated configuration to control the output now.

With all the new changes to PipelineOptions, this is actually the intended behavior.

Please close PR at your convenience.
Of course, you can also respond here, on BEAM-88, or on Beam mailing list with new comments on updated behavior.
This PR was merged, can be closed.
@dhalperi I planned to add new tests regarding latest comments. Please, take the lead on this as I won't be able to work on it before next week. Thanks !

1 Unknown Licenses

This have been now successfully tested on real dataflow pipeline (previously it wasn't working when I tried to use the runner code from master, but worked smoothly when I fell back to 0.1.0-incubating).

Hello, is there any blocking reason why this has not been merged ?
This will make the spark runner lighter and also from an architecture point of view it makes sense too.
I can confirm that failure. It should certainly succeed. I'm looking into it.

From a quick search it looks like the failure of `apache-rat:check` is working as intended (for some definition of "intended") according to [this thread](https://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/creadur-dev/201305.mbox/%3C518C03C0.3070806%40blueyonder.co.uk%3E) which I found through [this issue](https://github.com/dkpro/jweb1t/issues/3).

The fix suggested is to invoke the plugin only through `mvn verify`. But if that succeeded, we would expect Jenkins to succeed, since it is currently green outside this PR.
@charlesccychen Is this ready per our in-person discussion yesterday?

I have identified two issues that may prevent you from finding the real problem:
1. We have only _configured_ the RAT plugin in the release profile, which Jenkins uses. We probably meant to only _execute_ it in the `release` profile, but configuration should be global. So you can get the proper excludes on the command line with `-Prelease`. I will fix this separately.
2. RAT includes defaults for IDEs to exclude things like Eclipse's `.settings` and `.classpath` but the exclude patterns are not correct in the presence of subprojects. I will also fix this.

When I fix these two issues locally, the remaining RAT failure is `runners/gearpump/README.md`. Obviously we want it. The issue is that your `README.md` needs to have the Apache license header in a comment. See the source code for any of the other `README.md` files.

I would fix this for you and merge to a feature branch, but since it is a licensing issue I think it best that you make the edits.
For non-`Serializable` types, the fallback coder provider will throw `CannotProvideCoderException` and the coder registry will move on to the next attempt to provide a coder.
R: @robertwb Yes, the changes we settled on can use the same interface.

Please feel free to reword any package info -- I made things up.

Also, it looks like from the [existing Javadoc](http://beam.incubator.apache.org/javadoc/0.1.0-incubating/) that we prefer active voice ("Provides ..." "Defines ...") so I will rewrite in a next pass.
LGTM in the sense that we can get the enforcement in now and polish the particulars later. Any comments or refinements you do now are bonus IMO.

I don't know enough about what information type hints provide to comment deeply. Places where a transform "has a coder" worry me, because it is really PCollections that have coders.

And that's more than enough reviewers! But @bjchambers might have insights too :-)
@amitsela ready for a look. Also, no rush -- we can always fix these later; the important thing is to turn on the checkstyle check for future modules :)

R: @dhalperi note added dependency for Dataflow runner
R: @amitsela I added the `os-maven-plugin` to the Spark runner's pom. We have a transitive dependency that is somewhat badly behaved, for now. Once #539 goes in, it may no longer be necessary; I haven't looked closely. The transitive dependency may also be fixed by upstream upgrades by the time it becomes relevant.

I saw your question about tests.

For unit tests, I bet you can either mock or fake out the Kinesis library. That way we can test the code without relying on the service.

For integration tests: I'm assuming that there's no "free, public" Kinesis installation anywhere nor a single-machine version we can run? For KafkaIO, we run a local Kafka instance during unit tests. For several other services, we have an Apache Beam account where we have set it up specifically for testing. We may need to set up something similar for continuous integration testing of Kinesis. We'll have to figure out how we could get accounts, etc. with the right Apache control to do so.

As far as writing an end-to-end test.. If you look at [BigtableIO tests, e.g., BigtableReadIT](https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform/src/test/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/gcp/bigtable/BigtableReadIT.java) you'll see how those are set up. They are setup as Surefire integration tests (disabled by default) and they typically rely on pipeline options to be set in the environment variables + manually turning them on in order to run. In this manner, someone with access to a Kinesis installation can run the test by setting up the right test pipeline options.

In terms of things we need to do before merging .. someone can run your integration test manually and defer Jenkins-ifying it until later.

When you say "run this on real Dataflow" can you say more?
- Beam HEAD with the Google Cloud Dataflow runner?
- Google Cloud Dataflow SDK for Java 1.6.0?

something else?

More info, I can look into it.

Finally, I wanted to say thanks for porting forward from your PR against the Dataflow SDK to the Beam SDK here. It's really awesome to see how this has progressed from [our original discussion on StackOverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/34118103/how-custom-unbounded-sources-work-in-google-cloud-dataflow/34164264#34164264) :)
I'm a little confused why TextIO itself doesn't or can't do the validation? Because we don't expect to have the right IOChannelFactories registered at pipeline submission time?
@kennknowles Thanks for the thorough explanation. I think we are good to go this time.
Though I'm not sure what's the issue with Travis. I'll take a look once I'm near a computer.
I think the failures were due to slowing down the pvalue gc detection test just enough to cause this to timeout (due to not emitting output for a while?). Pushed a change.
